H0.text: The time of day is what the coach is most likely measuring with the stopwatch while standing at the finish line of a race.

H1.text: The distance of the race is what the coach is most likely measuring with the stopwatch while standing at the finish line.

H2.text: The time it took to run the race is what the coach, standing at the finish line and holding a stopwatch, is most likely measuring.

H3.text: The number of steps taken by the runners is what the coach is most likely measuring with the stopwatch at the finish line of a race.

A4.text: The device is used when time periods must be measured precisely and with a minimum of complications. Laboratory experiments and sporting events like sprints are good examples.

A5.text: Its first use was in ski racing but was later used by the World University Games in Moscow, Russia, the U.S. NCAA, and in the Olympic trials.
